title: Hotdog-Sandwich Taxonomy Framework

prerequisites: Secure buy-in from key stakeholder groups
steps.outcome: Authoritative body to define classification standards
risks: Stakeholders may resist centralized taxonomic authority
Commission could become mired in ideological gridlock

prerequisites: Commission has defined clear classification criteria
Stakeholders agree to accept dual-classification approach
steps.outcome: Hotdogs can be classified as both sandwiches and unique food items
risks: Some stakeholders may reject hybrid classification as unsatisfactory
Practical implementation challenges for regulations, menus, etc.

prerequisites: Taxonomy Commission has authority to make binding rulings
Stakeholders agree to abide by Commission decisions
steps.outcome: Clear processes to adjudicate classification disagreements
risks: Stakeholders may still resist Commission rulings
Dispute resolution could become overly bureaucratic

prerequisites: Dual-classification system and dispute resolution mechanisms in place
Stakeholders aligned on consistent public messaging
steps.outcome: General public understands and accepts hotdog taxonomy framework
risks: Polarized groups may undermine public education efforts
Some consumers may still resist the hybrid classification

steps.action: Periodically Review and Refine the Framework
prerequisites: Ongoing monitoring of implementation and stakeholder feedback
Taxonomy Commission has authority to make updates as needed
steps.outcome: Taxonomy remains responsive to evolving food culture and technology
risks: Stakeholders may resist changes to established classification system
Review process could become overly politicized

resource_requirements: Diverse multi-stakeholder commission with legal/regulatory expertise
Public relations and communications resources for education campaign
Funding for research, public forums, and implementation support
